All worlds and models should work without any changes.

values.description:
In pull request #594, `${PROJECT_SOURCE_DIR}/gazebo` was removed from the include path. This is a follow on that removes `${PROJECT_BINARY_DIR}/gazebo` from the include path as well. The only includes that need to be modified are:
~~~
-#include "gazebo_config.h"
+#include "gazebo/gazebo_config.h"
~~~
The CMakeLists.txt and code_check.sh script are changed as well.
values.title: Fix includes (follow-up to pull request #594)

+#include "gazebo/gazebo_config.h"

The CMakeLists.txt and code_check.sh script are changed as well.

values.description:
The code coverage report [is not very nice](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-coverage-precise-amd64/clover/?) for test coverage of our URDF parser and the comment on issue #758 about a problem with URDF parsing performance motivated this pull request.

* Unit testing file is included: is only testing the simple case and should be expanded to real cases but it is a starting point.
* Performance file: is running five time the parsing on atlas.urdf imported from drcsim
values.title: Testing (unit + performance) for URDF parser

* Unit testing file is included: is only testing the simple case and should be expanded to real cases but it is a starting point.
* Performance file: is running five time the parsing on atlas.urdf imported from drcsim

values.description:
There are some compilation errors with gazebo_1.8 when used with the latest versions of certain dependencies, as discussed in #657.

The change to World.hh involves removal of a variable that we weren't using and allows compilation with the latest protobuf.

The changes to Param.hh and QTestFixture.hh are related to a qt bug ([QTBUG-22829](https://bugreports.qt-project.org/browse/QTBUG-22829)), which involves the moc compiler failing if certain boost headers are included (`boost/lexical_cast.hpp` and `boost/program_options.hpp` definitely cause the problem with boost 1.53 and qt4). The fix involves wrapping `#include` tags in an #ifdef. Since it is a QT bug, one approach is to wrap all includes in files that get parsed by moc (should be limited to `gazebo/gui/*`).

Rather than a blanket approach, I managed to fix compilation by wrapping two include statements, one of which is in `sdf/interface/Param.hh`. This file shouldn't have to worry about a QT bug, but it is much simpler to make the change here than in the many files in `gazebo/gui/`.
values.title: Fix compilation errors with latest protobuf and QTBUG-22829 (part fix of #657)

summary.raw:
There are some compilation errors with gazebo_1.8 when used with the latest versions of certain dependencies, as discussed in #657.

The change to World.hh involves removal of a variable that we weren't using and allows compilation with the latest protobuf.

The changes to Param.hh and QTestFixture.hh are related to a qt bug ([QTBUG-22829](https://bugreports.qt-project.org/browse/QTBUG-22829)), which involves the moc compiler failing if certain boost headers are included (`boost/lexical_cast.hpp` and `boost/program_options.hpp` definitely cause the problem with boost 1.53 and qt4). The fix involves wrapping `#include` tags in an #ifdef. Since it is a QT bug, one approach is to wrap all includes in files that get parsed by moc (should be limited to `gazebo/gui/*`).

Rather than a blanket approach, I managed to fix compilation by wrapping two include statements, one of which is in `sdf/interface/Param.hh`. This file shouldn't have to worry about a QT bug, but it is much simpler to make the change here than in the many files in `gazebo/gui/`.
summary.html:
There are some compilation errors with gazebo_1.8 when used with the latest versions of certain dependencies, as discussed in #657.

The change to World.hh involves removal of a variable that we weren't using and allows compilation with the latest protobuf.

The changes to Param.hh and QTestFixture.hh are related to a qt bug (QTBUG-22829), which involves the moc compiler failing if certain boost headers are included (boost/lexical_cast.hpp and boost/program_options.hpp definitely cause the problem with boost 1.53 and qt4). The fix involves wrapping #include tags in an #ifdef. Since it is a QT bug, one approach is to wrap all includes in files that get parsed by moc (should be limited to gazebo/gui/*).

Rather than a blanket approach, I managed to fix compilation by wrapping two include statements, one of which is in sdf/interface/Param.hh. This file shouldn't have to worry about a QT bug, but it is much simpler to make the change here than in the many files in gazebo/gui/.

values.title: export gazebo lib dirs and plugin lib dirs in cmake config

values.description:
I would like to back to use "RelWithDebInfo" to build gazebo packages. While this is can be done from releasing tools with current gazebo code, I prefer to keep in sync the default build mode with packages build mode.

Changes implies:

* O3 -> O2 which did not show a big improvement in the past. I run a [jenkins performance comparisson](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/performance-comparisson-release-modes/performance/?) where runs 3,4,5 are with O3 and runs 6,7,8 are with O2 and results does not show a big drop to stop this change.
* Use RelWithDebInfo will bring back the debugging symbols (-g) 
* Assertions will be enabled again, since there is no -DNDEBUG.
values.title: Use RelWithDebInfo mode for compiling as default

summary.raw:
I would like to back to use "RelWithDebInfo" to build gazebo packages. While this is can be done from releasing tools with current gazebo code, I prefer to keep in sync the default build mode with packages build mode.

I run a [jenkins performance comparisson](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/performance-comparisson-release-modes/performance/?) where runs 3,4,5 are with O3 and runs 6,7,8 are with O2 and results does not show a big drop to stop this change.
* Use RelWithDebInfo will bring back the debugging symbols (-g) 
* Assertions will be enabled again, since there is no -DNDEBUG.
summary.html:
I would like to back to use "RelWithDebInfo" to build gazebo packages. While this is can be done from releasing tools with current gazebo code, I prefer to keep in sync the default build mode with packages build mode.

Changes implies:

  • O3 -> O2 which did not show a big improvement in the past. I run a jenkins performance comparisson where runs 3,4,5 are with O3 and runs 6,7,8 are with O2 and results does not show a big drop to stop this change.
  • Use RelWithDebInfo will bring back the debugging symbols (-g)
  • Assertions will be enabled again, since there is no -DNDEBUG.

values.description:
The goal of this change is to remove the need, in the common case, to source Gazebo's `setup.sh`.  This is accomplished by compiling into the code, as defaults, the same values that are written into the environment variable settings in `setup.sh`.  For each environment variable, if it's not set, we take the compiled-in default; if the environment variable is set, it takes precedence over the default.

Along the way, I moved the setting of these defaults into one place, in the toplevel `CMakeLists.txt`.  Then `setup.sh.in` contains only single variable replacements, without any logic or knowledge of directory structure.

It's still OK to source `setup.sh`.  And if you want to build upon the default values (e.g., extend `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH`), then you should first source `setup.sh` to get the defaults, then add to them (this is how drcsim's `setup.sh` will continue to work).

I did not compile in the default value for `LD_LIBRARY_PATH`, and I removed the setting of it from `setup.sh.in`.  I did that because, as far as I can tell, that setting is not needed.  If that's wrong, let me know.
values.title: Add compile-time defaults for env vars (issue #781)

summary.raw:
The goal of this change is to remove the need, in the common case, to source Gazebo's `setup.sh`.  This is accomplished by compiling into the code, as defaults, the same values that are written into the environment variable settings in `setup.sh`.  For each environment variable, if it's not set, we take the compiled-in default; if the environment variable is set, it takes precedence over the default.

Along the way, I moved the setting of these defaults into one place, in the toplevel `CMakeLists.txt`.  Then `setup.sh.in` contains only single variable replacements, without any logic or knowledge of directory structure.

It's still OK to source `setup.sh`.  And if you want to build upon the default values (e.g., extend `GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH`), then you should first source `setup.sh` to get the defaults, then add to them (this is how drcsim's `setup.sh` will continue to work).

I did not compile in the default value for `LD_LIBRARY_PATH`, and I removed the setting of it from `setup.sh.in`.  I did that because, as far as I can tell, that setting is not needed.  If that's wrong, let me know.
summary.html:
The goal of this change is to remove the need, in the common case, to source Gazebo's setup.sh. This is accomplished by compiling into the code, as defaults, the same values that are written into the environment variable settings in setup.sh. For each environment variable, if it's not set, we take the compiled-in default; if the environment variable is set, it takes precedence over the default.

Along the way, I moved the setting of these defaults into one place, in the toplevel CMakeLists.txt. Then setup.sh.in contains only single variable replacements, without any logic or knowledge of directory structure.

It's still OK to source setup.sh. And if you want to build upon the default values (e.g., extend GAZEBO_MODEL_PATH), then you should first source setup.sh to get the defaults, then add to them (this is how drcsim's setup.sh will continue to work).

I did not compile in the default value for LD_LIBRARY_PATH, and I removed the setting of it from setup.sh.in. I did that because, as far as I can tell, that setting is not needed. If that's wrong, let me know.

values.description:
Manpages are in markdown format and will be converted by using ronn, which has an ubuntu package ruby-ronn. They are converted and compressed in the moment of install them.

To complete the pull request, we need info about gzphysics and gzsensors so please, feel free to update the pull request with it or any other fix to man page information.
values.title: Manpages for gazebo binaries

values.description: Modification to use TEST_TYPE as name, not only for test results, but to generate test filenames. This will allow to run test suite by types, in the form of ```make test ARGS="-R UNIT_" ```, while keeping categorized test results.
values.title: Use TEST_TYPE in test names to be able to select which to run

values.description: It doesn't make much sense to me that gzdbg is sent to the console, instead of a log file. Sometimes a ton of debug info can be produced, and it makes it really hard to pick out more important warnings and errors.
values.title: Send debug to log instead of console.

summary.raw: It doesn't make much sense to me that gzdbg is sent to the console, instead of a log file. Sometimes a ton of debug info can be produced, and it makes it really hard to pick out more important warnings and errors.
summary.html: It doesn't make much sense to me that gzdbg is sent to the console, instead of a log file. Sometimes a ton of debug info can be produced, and it makes it really hard to pick out more important warnings and errors.

values.reason: This is better solved on a case-to-case basis.

values.title: Fix spelling error in Server --help and add list of options for log encoding

values.description:
This pull request deprecates the built-in sdf parser and switches to using the sdformat package. This primarily involves changes to header files and CMakeLists.txt.

This pull request also refactors the `sdf::Element::GetValue*` functions to use templates, ie. `GetValueString` becomes `Get<std::string>`. This refactor touches many files. To see the diff without this refactor, I made a test branch [gazebo_1.9_smaller_diff](#!/osrf/gazebo/compare/gazebo_1.9..gazebo_1.9_smaller_diff) that has all the `GetValue*` functions changed. Using the [compare tool](#!/osrf/gazebo/compare/gazebo_1.9..gazebo_1.9_smaller_diff) shows a smaller diff.
values.title: Use external sdformat repository (gazebo_1.9 branch)

summary.raw:
This pull request deprecates the built-in sdf parser and switches to using the sdformat package. This primarily involves changes to header files and CMakeLists.txt.

This pull request also refactors the `sdf::Element::GetValue*` functions to use templates, ie. `GetValueString` becomes `Get<std::string>`. This refactor touches many files. To see the diff without this refactor, I made a test branch [gazebo_1.9_smaller_diff](#!/osrf/gazebo/compare/gazebo_1.9..gazebo_1.9_smaller_diff) that has all the `GetValue*` functions changed. Using the [compare tool](#!/osrf/gazebo/compare/gazebo_1.9..gazebo_1.9_smaller_diff) shows a smaller diff.
summary.html:
This pull request deprecates the built-in sdf parser and switches to using the sdformat package. This primarily involves changes to header files and CMakeLists.txt.

This pull request also refactors the sdf::Element::GetValue* functions to use templates, ie. GetValueString becomes Get<std::string>. This refactor touches many files. To see the diff without this refactor, I made a test branch gazebo_1.9_smaller_diff that has all the GetValue* functions changed. Using the compare tool shows a smaller diff.

values.description:
The following header files are included in the gazebo repository:
~~~
gazebo/common/Common.hh
gazebo/physics/Physics.hh
gazebo/rendering/Rendering.hh
gazebo/sensors/Sensors.hh
gazebo/transport/Transport.hh
~~~
and the following headers are auto-generated:

~~~
gazebo/common/common.hh
gazebo/physics/physics.hh
gazebo/rendering/rendering.hh
gazebo/sensors/sensors.hh
gazebo/transport/transport.hh
~~~
This will prevent successful installation on filesystems that aren't case-sensitive (such as the default filesystem for Mac OS X).

This pull request renames the header files by adding `Iface` (ie. `Physics.hh` => `PhysicsIface.hh`). It also changes the header guards in those files and the include statements in the rest of the repository.

This pull request will break any external packages that currently include these header files. A workaround is to always include the all-inclusive lowercase headers (ie. `physics.hh`). As such, this is targeted to default, intended for gazebo 2.0.
values.title: Fix #775: support for case-insensitive filesystems

summary.raw:
The following header files are included in the gazebo repository:
~~~
gazebo/common/Common.hh
gazebo/physics/Physics.hh
gazebo/rendering/Rendering.hh
gazebo/sensors/Sensors.hh
gazebo/transport/Transport.hh
~~~
and the following headers are auto-generated:

~~~
gazebo/common/common.hh
gazebo/physics/physics.hh
gazebo/rendering/rendering.hh
gazebo/sensors/sensors.hh
gazebo/transport/transport.hh
~~~
This will prevent successful installation on filesystems that aren't case-sensitive (such as the default filesystem for Mac OS X).

This pull request renames the header files by adding `Iface` (ie. `Physics.hh` => `PhysicsIface.hh`). It also changes the header guards in those files and the include statements in the rest of the repository.

This pull request will break any external packages that currently include these header files. A workaround is to always include the all-inclusive lowercase headers (ie. `physics.hh`). As such, this is targeted to default, intended for gazebo 2.0.
summary.html:
The following header files are included in the gazebo repository:

gazebo/common/Common.hh
gazebo/physics/Physics.hh
gazebo/rendering/Rendering.hh
gazebo/sensors/Sensors.hh
gazebo/transport/Transport.hh

and the following headers are auto-generated:

gazebo/common/common.hh
gazebo/physics/physics.hh
gazebo/rendering/rendering.hh
gazebo/sensors/sensors.hh
gazebo/transport/transport.hh

This will prevent successful installation on filesystems that aren't case-sensitive (such as the default filesystem for Mac OS X).

This pull request renames the header files by adding Iface (ie. Physics.hh => PhysicsIface.hh). It also changes the header guards in those files and the include statements in the rest of the repository.

This pull request will break any external packages that currently include these header files. A workaround is to always include the all-inclusive lowercase headers (ie. physics.hh). As such, this is targeted to default, intended for gazebo 2.0.

values.description:
Some proto files had bad "/// \interface <text>" definitions that cause one set of doxygen to overwrite another.

For example, the `joint_wrench.proto` would overwrite the `joint.proto` documentation because the first word after "/// \interface " was "Joint".

http://gazebosim.org/msgs/1.6.3/interfaceJoint.html

This pull-request  fixes that problem, and also adds a python script to check for this problem.

Here is the same file fixed:

http://gazebosim.org/msgs/1.9.0/interfaceJoint.html
values.title: Update documentation for proto messages

summary.raw:
Some proto files had bad "/// \interface <text>" definitions that cause one set of doxygen to overwrite another.

For example, the `joint_wrench.proto` would overwrite the `joint.proto` documentation because the first word after "/// \interface " was "Joint".

http://gazebosim.org/msgs/1.6.3/interfaceJoint.html

This pull-request  fixes that problem, and also adds a python script to check for this problem.

Here is the same file fixed:

http://gazebosim.org/msgs/1.9.0/interfaceJoint.html

For example, the joint_wrench.proto would overwrite the joint.proto documentation because the first word after "/// \interface " was "Joint".

values.description:
To test:

1. Do a complete build.
2. `touch` a .proto file in gazebo/msgs
3. `make` again, and it should regenerate the .pb.h and .pb.cc files and so forth
values.title: Fix build dependency in message generation (#247)

summary.raw:
To test:

1. Do a complete build.
2. `touch` a .proto file in gazebo/msgs
3. `make` again, and it should regenerate the .pb.h and .pb.cc files and so forth
summary.html:
To test:

  1. Do a complete build.
  2. touch a .proto file in gazebo/msgs
  3. make again, and it should regenerate the .pb.h and .pb.cc files and so forth

values.description:
This is the first of pull requests to fix the [119 errors](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/ubuntu-raring/job/gazebo-gazebo_1.9-devel-raring-amd64/18/cppcheckResult/?) reported by cppcheck in raring (if you look at default raring jenkins job, it had a bug and was using precise until yesterday).

Most of this pull request changes are:

* Unused variables
* Change all checks on STL containers which were using size() method when they really could use empty() method, which is better in terms of performance since the standard assures constant time on empty() but not on size() (probably for a vector is the same, but not for a list).

There is another important change to discuss. I removed the warning on "unused functions" since most of them look to me like part of a desired API. Feel free to comment about this change.

The rest of the [10 errors](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/ubuntu-raring/job/gazebo-any-devel-raring-amd64-no-gpu/4/cppcheckResult/?) are more interesting and deserve different pull requests.
values.title: Fix raring cppcheck warnings

Most of this pull request changes are:

* Unused variables
* Change all checks on STL containers which were using size() method when they really could use empty() method, which is better in terms of performance since the standard assures constant time on empty() but not on size() (probably for a vector is the same, but not for a list).

There is another important change to discuss. I removed the warning on "unused functions" since most of them look to me like part of a desired API. Feel free to comment about this change.

The rest of the [10 errors](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/ubuntu-raring/job/gazebo-any-devel-raring-amd64-no-gpu/4/cppcheckResult/?) are more interesting and deserve different pull requests.
summary.html:
This is the first of pull requests to fix the 119 errors reported by cppcheck in raring (if you look at default raring jenkins job, it had a bug and was using precise until yesterday).

Most of this pull request changes are:

  • Unused variables
  • Change all checks on STL containers which were using size() method when they really could use empty() method, which is better in terms of performance since the standard assures constant time on empty() but not on size() (probably for a vector is the same, but not for a list).

There is another important change to discuss. I removed the warning on "unused functions" since most of them look to me like part of a desired API. Feel free to comment about this change.

The rest of the 10 errors are more interesting and deserve different pull requests.

values.description:
Redo of pull request #630, fix for #775. Several header files (Common.hh, Gui.hh, Physics.hh, Rendering.hh, Sensors.hh, and Transport.hh) conflict with auto-generated headers (common.hh, gui.hh, physics.hh, rendering.hh, sensors.hh, and transport.hh) on case-insensitive filesystems. This pull request renames one set (ie. Common.hh to CommonIface.hh) and auto-generates a header that gives a deprecated warning if a case-sensitive filesystem is detected.

The meat of the changes are in the top 2 files (CmakeLists.txt and cmake/GazeboUtils.cmake) and the last file (tools/issue_775_generator.bash).

I've targeted to 1.9 so we can get 1.9 building on osx.
values.title: Fix for #775, deprecate headers that require case-sensitive filesystem

values.description:
cppcheck is [complaining](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/ubuntu-raring/job/gazebo-any-devel-raring-amd64-no-gpu/4/cppcheckResult/) about a bad use of std::remove in a list. I've never seen that before, but I would say that cppcheck is probably right.

My approach was converting it to own list remove method, using the already implemented Filter == operator overload which compares names.
values.title: cppcheck warn: proper remove in std::list

summary.raw:
cppcheck is [complaining](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/ubuntu-raring/job/gazebo-any-devel-raring-amd64-no-gpu/4/cppcheckResult/) about a bad use of std::remove in a list. I've never seen that before, but I would say that cppcheck is probably right.

My approach was converting it to own list remove method, using the already implemented Filter == operator overload which compares names.
summary.html:
cppcheck is complaining about a bad use of std::remove in a list. I've never seen that before, but I would say that cppcheck is probably right.

My approach was converting it to own list remove method, using the already implemented Filter == operator overload which compares names.

Since names were quite close to one of the paremeters, I'm assuming here that it was a programming bug.

values.description:
This pull request adds a GPS sensor and two supporting classes. It includes tests and an example world `test/worlds/gps_test.world` with gps sensors attached to pendulums.

`common::SphericalCoordinates` is a class for converting from Cartesian to spherical coordinates.

`sensors::Noise` is a class that can be used for adding noise to sensors. Currently several sensors are implementing sensor noise in their own way. This class is my proposal for reusing that code, which greatly simplifies the sdf definitions and testing. 

Depends on [sdformat pull request 36](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/36).
values.title: GPS sensor, new sensor noise class

summary.raw:
This pull request adds a GPS sensor and two supporting classes. It includes tests and an example world `test/worlds/gps_test.world` with gps sensors attached to pendulums.

`common::SphericalCoordinates` is a class for converting from Cartesian to spherical coordinates.

`sensors::Noise` is a class that can be used for adding noise to sensors. Currently several sensors are implementing sensor noise in their own way. This class is my proposal for reusing that code, which greatly simplifies the sdf definitions and testing. 

Depends on [sdformat pull request 36](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/36).
summary.html:
This pull request adds a GPS sensor and two supporting classes. It includes tests and an example world test/worlds/gps_test.world with gps sensors attached to pendulums.

common::SphericalCoordinates is a class for converting from Cartesian to spherical coordinates.

sensors::Noise is a class that can be used for adding noise to sensors. Currently several sensors are implementing sensor noise in their own way. This class is my proposal for reusing that code, which greatly simplifies the sdf definitions and testing.

Depends on sdformat pull request 36.

values.description:
**New additions**

  Decoding of audio files (wav, mp3, ogg)

  Playback of 3D audio using OpenAL

** Example World **

An example world has a audio source attached to a box, and an audio sink attached to a sphere. The box starts off the ground, and will play on contact with the ground plane.

    gazebo -u worlds/openal.world

** Tests **

Unit test for AudioDecoder and OpenAL. There are no tests to make sure the audio played correctly. Any ideas?

**Coverage**
  
   *OpenAL.cc* Function: 100% Condition: 81%

   *AudioDecoder.cc* Function: 100% Condition: 85%
values.title: OpenAL Integration
